Then, with a damp unbleached cotton cloth, staff uses circular motions to delicately remove any leftover paper and shoji glue from the frame.

Shoji screen paper is fragile and easily damaged. Curious to know how we replace it every year for the new season? First, the old paper is carefully peeled off to reveal the frame of the shoji screen. Pieces of paper still on the frame are removed by hand (Part 1/2) https://t.co/cuAzeSM9e6

Japanese gardens prevent moss from frosting over the winter by covering it with pine needles. Every Fall, this is how our staff transforms the tea garden to welcome the Omotesenke tea gathering: a seasonal element that emphasizes the stepping stones leading to the tea house. https://t.co/cvU1O6g7wk

In Japan, rain chains or kusari-doi (ÈéñÊ®ã, lit. chain gutter) are both functional and aesthetically pleasing ways of directing rain off rooftops. While some can be very decorative and elaborate - especially in Buddhist Temples - this one is made in a simple "double ring" style. https://t.co/XMb6FhR4TV

Have you spotted this pair of Geta in the kitchen? Geta (‰∏ãÈßÑ) are traditional wooden sandals commonly worn with Kimono, or during the summer with Yukata. Shofuso‚Äôs murals were made by Japanese painter Hiroshi Senju. Many of the his large-scale works are housed in the Hiroshi Senju Museum in Karuizawa. Shofuso‚Äôs murals are the only Senju installation currently on view in the US. Support Shofuso Restoration https://t.co/Bzb58DUz8J https://t.co/SVVgyLFwsx

In-person tours are available for groups of 10-40 people, Wednesdays-Fridays starting 11am. We also offer tea tasting, traditional Kamishibai storytelling, and fish food to feed our Koi. For more info please contact Michael Lewis, Program Coordinator, at mlewis@japanphilly.org. https://t.co/S656755siM

Throughout the 2022 season, Taiko instructor Mac Evans will lead a weekly series of Taiko workshops just outside Shofuso! Workshops will start at 1:30pm each Saturday through November 5 (not on May 14 and October 1). Sign up online or walk up in person: https://t.co/WiF3BX8Knt https://t.co/dD4IhARLUw

Explore the beauty of Japan through the eyes of printmaking! Explore Shofuso and create art inspired by the nature around you. You will learn modern and traditional forms of printing such as hanko, ukiyo-e, leaf rubbings and gyotaku. @WestParkFest
